fieldset.xf:hint: Information about the origin of the resource, including place of origin or publication, publisher/originator, and dates associated with the resource.

xf:select1.xf:label: Language:
xf:select1.xf:hint: The language used within Origin Information is specified here, if this language is different from the language noted in Language of Resource. The most common languages have been moved to the top of the list.

xf:select1.xf:label: xml:lang:
xf:select1.xf:hint:
This attribute is used to specify the language used within an element, using specifications in RFC 3066. RFC 3066 uses the two-character ISO 639-1 codes along with three-character ISO 639-2 codes for those languages not given in 639-1.
The recommendation is not to use xml:lang, but to use Language.

xf:select1.xf:label: Script:
xf:select1.xf:hint: If the Origin Information is in a non-Latin script, note here the script utilised. As transliterations use the Latin script, the Transliteration attribute becomes unneccesary when Latin script is chosen.

xf:select1.xf:label: Transliteration:
xf:select1.xf:hint: If the Origin Information is transliterated, note here the transliteration scheme utilised. As transliterations are romanisations, the Script attribute becomes unneccesary.

fieldset.xf:hint: Record in Place the place names associated with the origin of a resource, i.e., its creation, publication, issuance, etc. Place should be omitted if no information about the originating place of the resource is known. Input in Place is performed through Place Terms. If one Place has several Place Terms, e.g. the name of a country and the name of a city, repeat Place Term as necessary. If a resource has several places of origin, repeat Place.

Use Place Term to record the textual or code form of the place. If the place is a country, the name of the country can be selected from the MARC country code list or the ISO3166 standard list of country names. If the place is not a country, add Place Term and write the place name (e.g. city name) with Type set to "Text".

xf:select1.xf:label: Type:
xf:select1.xf:hint: Type indicates whether the place is expressed in a coded or textual form.

xf:select1.xf:label: Authority:
xf:select1.xf:hint: The name of the authoritative list for a controlled value is recorded here.

xf:select1.xf:label: Place Term:
xf:select1.xf:hint: Names of countries (and US states) according to the marccountry standard list.

xf:select1.xf:label: Place Term:
xf:select1.xf:hint: Names of countries according to the iso3166 standard list.

xf:input.xf:label: Place Term:
xf:input.xf:hint: Uncoded place terms, i.e. place terms that have not been chosen in an authority file.

fieldset.xf:hint: The name of the entity that is the originator for a resource, i.e. that has published, printed, distributed, released, issued, or produced it.

xf:input.xf:label: Publisher:
xf:input.xf:hint: The name of the entity that is the originator for a resource, i.e. that has published, printed, distributed, released, issued, or produced it. Information about an institution responsible for digitising and delivering online a previously published resource should be included in Note, rather than Publisher.

fieldset.xf:hint: Information identifying the version of the resource. Resources that constitute the same edition generally embody essentially the same content. If no edition statement applies to the resource, leave Edition empty.

xf:input.xf:label: Edition:
xf:input.xf:hint: Information identifying the version of the resource.

fieldset.xf:hint:
In Issuance one records how the resource is issued. It may be used with the following values: continuing and monographic.
A continuing resource is issued over time with no predetermined conclusion. Continuing resources include serials/periodicals and ongoing integrating resources, i.e. those that are continuously updated. A monographic resource is either complete in one part or intended to be completed in a finite number of separate parts.

xf:select1.xf:label: Issuance:
xf:select1.xf:hint: Issuance records how the resource is issued. It may be used with the following values: continuing and monographic.

fieldset.xf:hint: Frequency is used to define the publication pattern of the item.

xf:select1.xf:label: Authority:
xf:select1.xf:hint: The name of the authoritative list for a controlled value is recorded here.

xf:select1.xf:label: Frequency:
xf:select1.xf:hint: Frequency is used to define the publication pattern of the item.

fieldset.xf:hint:
Dates can be expressed in several different formats. The following values are used with the Encoding: w3cdtf, iso8601, marc. The recommended encoding is w3cdtf.
In all three encodings, a specific year (e.g. "1938") is encoded in the same way; the three standards differ in how to encode time points of time year. According to w3cdtf dates follow the pattern: YYYY-MM-DD, i.e. with dashes between year, month and day, and with all years have four, all months two and all days two digits. If hours, minutes, and seconds are needed, the following pattern is used: YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss.
If Encoding is not given any value, the input is assumed to be textual. This means that any way of noting time can be used. If possible, use a coded value.
The date that the resource was published, released, or issued.

xf:select1.xf:label: Point:
xf:select1.xf:hint:
Use Point if you wish to record a span of time, e.g. 1912-1914. The following values are used with Point: start, end. Repeat the date field and choose "start" in one and "end" in the other repetition, and enter the appropriate dates in the two date fields.
If no point attribute is specified, a date noted in Date is assumed to be a single date.

xf:select1.xf:label: Key Date:
xf:select1.xf:hint: One can record different events that may be important in the life of a resource in a number of different date elements. When multiple date elements apply but would contain identical data, one may choose to use only one of the relevant date elements. In this case, mark one and only one such date element as a key date by choosing "date is key date" in Key Date.

xf:select1.xf:label: Qualifier:
xf:select1.xf:hint: When a date is uncertain or supplied by the cataloger, indicate this through the use of Qualifier rather than inserting characters such as "ca.", brackets, or a question mark as part of the date string. When only a decade is known, enter a date range for the entire decade and mark the date as questionable. When only a century is known, enter a date range for the entire century and mark the date as questionable.

xf:input.xf:label: Date Issued:
xf:input.xf:hint: The date that the resource was published, released, or issued.
